stimulusHtml: A student conducts an experiment with tiny charged oil drops suspended in an observation chamber. One individual oil drop is found to have a net charge of −3.2×10−19C. While suspended, the drop is seen to split into two smaller drops, which immediately move horizontally away from each other. One drop has an acceleration that is three times the acceleration of the other drop. The student claims that one drop has a charge of −0.8×10−19C and the other drop has a charge of −2.4×10−19C, a ratio of three to one, to account for the different accelerations. Is the student’s conclusion reasonable? Why or why not?
choicesHtml: Yes. The values of the charges account for the force on each drop, resulting in different accelerations.
Yes. There is no constraint on the value of the charges on each drop.
No. Neither of the charges is a multiple of the elementary charge. A difference in mass will account for the different accelerations.
No. The charge on a drop will always divide equally between two smaller drops into which it splits.
